ch.unige.ng.ops.crossover
Class DoubleOffspringCrossOver<T extends GlobalIndividual>

java.lang.Object
  ch.unige.ng.ops.crossover.DoubleOffspringCrossOver<T>
All Implemented Interfaces:
Crossover<T>, Operator<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
BasicOnePointCrossOver, DisruptiveCrossover, SubTreeCrossover, SwapCrossover, TwoPointsCrossover, UniformCrossover, VarSizeOnePointCrossOver
public abstract class DoubleOffspringCrossOver<T extends GlobalIndividual>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Operator<T>, Crossover<T>

Common base for all the operator that process two Individuals to make one new Individual.

This class has to be extended by subclasses that crossover two elements.

Version:
17-sept-2004
Author:
Jean-Luc Falcone

operate

public void operate(Population<T> pop,
                    Selector<T> selector,
                    Context context,
                    int number)
Description copied from interface: Operator
This method process a list Individual. This Method choose a list of Individuals with the selector from the first population and add processed copies in the second.

Specified by:
operate in interface Operator<T extends GlobalIndividual>
Parameters:
pop - the Population
selector - selector
context - The context of the operations. Some operators have to know a random generator number, the current generation, ... All these values are put in this object
number - number of Individual to process

operate

public void operate(Group<T> source,
                    IGroup<T> destination,
                    Selector<T> selector,
                    Context context)
Description copied from interface: Operator
This method has to operate the source and put it into destination. Each individual has to be modified. To be sure that there will be no memory leaks, you have to call the remove function. The number of individuals in the destination has to be the same as in the destination.

This function is quite equivalent to operate(Population,Selector,Context,number), but it is used if we want by example to make a pipe. The output individuals are the inputs of the next Operator.

It is really important that you do not self release the elements in the source, It can be in the default population.

You should not create new individual. The idea is to transform the individuals that are in source.

Specified by:
operate in interface Operator<T extends GlobalIndividual>
Parameters:
source - The population in which we want to pop elements. It is copies of the default population
destination - The population in which the new individuals are put It is the new population.
selector - The selector used to select the individuals
context - The context.

crossover

public T crossover(T mate1,
                   T mate2,
                   Context context)
Description copied from interface: Crossover
This method makes a crossover between two mates, only one offspring is created, classes that generate more than one have to select one randomly from the list.

Specified by:
crossover in interface Crossover<T extends GlobalIndividual>
Returns:
an individual that is the child of mate1 and mate2, only one individual has to be created

                                           T mate2,
                                           IGroup<T> destination,
                                           Context context)
This method crossover two individuals and creates two offsprings. These two offsprings have to be created put into destination

mate1 - It is a reference of the individuals
mate2 - It is a reference
destination - The population in which new individuals will be put.

Parameters:
mate1 - It is a reference of the individuals, children has to be created
mate2 - It is a reference
destination - the population in which the new individual will be put
context -
